OVERVIEW:
MLRA(s)--155
Depth class--Very deep
Drainage class--Subaqueous
Water depth range--0.65 to 3.50 meters
Parent material--Coarse-loamy estuarine deposits
Geomorphic location--Lagoon bottom and lagoon channels
Slope range for Series--0 to 1 percent
Mean annual air temperature--22 degrees C (71.6 degrees F)
Mean annual precipitation--1300 millimeters (51.1 inches)
Mean annual water temperature--24.7 degrees C (76.6 degrees F)

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, mixed, subactive, nonacid, hyperthermic Typic Haplowassents

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON: Ittsanapper fine sandy loam on a west facing, 0.5 percent linear slope bare mud lagoon bottom under 1.80 meters of estuarine water. Tidal range is 24 centimeters. (Colors are for moist soil unless otherwise noted).
Aseg1--0 to 6 centimeters; dark greenish gray (10Y 4/1) fine sandy loam; massive; slightly sticky, nonplastic; nonfluid; 3 percent shell fragments; slight sulfurous odor; moderately alkaline (pH 8.2); clear boundary.
Aseg2--6 to 19 centimeters; greenish gray (10Y 5/1) fine sandy loam; massive; slightly sticky, nonplastic; nonfluid; 8 percent shell fragments; slight sulfurous odor; moderately alkaline (pH 8.3); abrupt boundary. (0 to 58 centimeters thick)
2Cseg1--19 to 43 centimeters; greenish gray (5GY 5/1) extremely shelly fine sandy loam; massive; slightly sticky, nonplastic; nonfluid; 70 percent shell fragments; moderate sulfurous odor; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4); abrupt boundary.
3Cseg2--43 to 72 centimeters; greenish gray (10Y 5/1) fine sandy loam;  massive; slightly sticky, nonplastic; nonfluid; 2 percent shell fragments; slight sulfurous odor; moderately alkaline (pH 8.0); gradual boundary.
3Cseg3--72 to 88 centimeters; greenish gray (5GY 5/1) silt loam; massive; slightly sticky, nonplastic; slightly fluid; 3 percent shell fragments; moderate sulfurous odor; strongly alkaline, (pH 8.5); clear boundary.
3Cseg4--88 to 120 centimeters; greenish gray (5GY 5/1) silty clay loam; massive; moderately sticky, slightly plastic; very fluid; 3 percent shell fragments; moderate sulfurous odor; moderately alkaline, (pH 8.1); gradual boundary.
3Cseg5--120 to 168 centimeters; greenish gray (5GY 5/1) fine sandy loam; massive; slightly sticky, nonplastic; nonfluid; 3 percent shell fragments; slight sulfurous odor; moderately alkaline, (pH 8.2); gradual boundary.
3Cseg6--168 to 203 centimeters; dark greenish gray (5GY 4/1) fine sandy loam; massive; slightly sticky, nonplastic; nonfluid; 3 percent shell fragments; moderate sulfurous odor; strongly alkaline, (pH 8.5); clear boundary.
3Cseg7--203 to 220 centimeters; dark greenish gray (5GY 4/1) silt loam; massive; slightly sticky, nonplastic; slightly fluid; 3 percent shell fragments; moderate sulfurous odor; strongly alkaline, (pH 8.6).

TYPE LOCATION.content:
TYPE LOCATION: Brevard County, Florida; Cape Canaveral, approximately 2,952 feet north-northeast of the road intersections of Samuel C Phillips Parkway (401) and Payne Way and approximately 4,904 feet northwest of the intersections of Samuel C Phillips Parkway (401) and South Patrol Road, just north of Port Canaveral. USGS topographic quadrangle: Cape Canaveral, Florida.
Latitude--28.4267395
Longitude-- -80.6136071
Datum--WGS84
Coordinate source--Manually entered from GPS

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Depth to bedrock--Greater than 200 centimeters
Particle--size control section--Less than 18 percent clay
Soil moisture--Continuously inundated
Reaction throughout--Slightly alkaline to strongly alkaline (pH 7.4 to 9.0)
Oxidized reaction--?
Electrical conductivity (1:5 soil-water) throughout--0.6 dS/m or greater
Depth to sulfidic materials (oxidized pH4.0)--?
Manner of failure--Nonfluid to moderately fluid
Shell fragments throughout--0 to 90 percent (higher ranges occur in thin individual horizons)
Aseg-
Hue--2.5Y to 10Y or is neutral
Value--2.5 to 5
Chroma--1 or less
Texture--Sandy loam, fine sandy loam or loamy fine sand
Cseg horizon-
Hue--5Y, 10Y, 5GY, 10GY, 5B, 5G or is neutral
Value--3 to 7
Chroma--1 or less
Textures--Fine sandy loam, sandy loam, silt loam, silty clay loam or loamy fine sand with shelly, very shelly or extremely shelly analogs
Thin strata of sandy material are found in some pedons.
Some areas are underlain at a depth greater than 100 centimeters by buried fluviomarine deposits with buried albic and spodic horizons.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES: There are no competing series.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content:
GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:
Parent material--Coarse-loamy estuarine deposits
Landscape--Coastal lagoons
Landform--Lagoon bottoms and lagoon channels
Slope--0 to 1 percent
Mean annual precipitation--970 to 1570 millimeters (38 to 62 inches)
Mean annual air temperature--20 to 25 degrees C (69 to 77 degrees F)
Water salinity range--9 to 22 parts per thousand
Frost-free period--365 days

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content:
GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS: These are the Broadaxe, Cocharan, Crawl, and Tea Hammock soils.
Broadaxe soils--are on submerged wave-cut platforms and have abundant buried and preserved spodic horizons in their fluviomarine deposits.
Cocharan soils--are on mainland coves and have limnic materials.
Crawl soils--are on nearby anthropogenic landforms in deep (> 4 meters) dredge channels primarily used for navigation throughout the waterway
Tea Hammock soils--are also on nearby anthropogenic landforms consisting of dredge deposits shoals

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content:
DRAINAGE AND SATURATED HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY:
Drainage class--Subaqueous
Saturated hydraulic conductivity--Moderately high or high
Soil moisture regime--Peraquic
Soil is continuously inundated by saline and brackish water.

USE AND VEGETATION.content:
USE AND VEGETATION:
Major uses--Used for recreational boating, fishing, and swimming, marinas, mooring fields, and commercial shellfish harvesting; benthic species include tubeworms, clams, crabs, scallops and juvenile finfish
Native vegetation--Dominant vegetation is driven by water quality and quantity within subaqueous systems. Under excellent water quality these soils support seagrass species including but not limited to shoalweed (Halodule wrightii), manatee grass (Syringodium filiforme), and Englemann's seagrass (Halophila englemannii). Under degraded / poor water quality seagrass may be replaced by rooted eukaryotic macroalgae in the green (Chlorophyta), red (Rhodophyta), and brown (Phaeophyta) algae families. Caulerpa prolifera (Chlorophyta) is often dominant. Vegetative cover ranges from 0 through 80 percent.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content:
DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:
General area--Located along the coasts of Indian River Lagoon, Florida
Land Resource Regions--U - Florida Subtropical Fruit, Truck Crop, and Range Region
MLRA(s)--155
Extent--Small

REGIONAL OFFICE.content: SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (SSRO) RESPONSIBLE: Auburn, Alabama

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:
Diagnostic horizons and features in this pedon include--
-Peraquic soil moisture regime--Positive soil water potential (permanently submerged) at the soil surface. (under 1.8 meters of salt water).
-Particle-size control section--The zone from 0 to 100 centimeters (0 to 40 inches).
-Ochric epipedon--The zone from 0 to 19 centimeters (Aseg1 and Aseg2 horizons).
-Lithologic discontinuity--19 to 43 centimeters (2Cseg1 horizon) and 43 to 220 centimeters (3Cseg2, 3Cseg3, 3Cseg4, 3Cseg5, 3Cseg6, and 3Cseg7 horizons)
-Sulfidic materials--?.
-n-value >0.7--The zone from 72 to 120 cm (3Cseg3 and 3Cseg4 horizons) and 203 to 220 centimeters (3Cseg7 horizon).
-Taxonomic version--Keys to Soil Taxonomy, 13th edition (2022)
